reviews.review_text: Final Edit, I can say that my computer is 100% fixed. Raising to 4 stars, and would have been a 5 had the Unit worked correctly on arrival. Okay, I've just gotten my PC back from ASUS Customer support, and after a brief test drive, all signs are looking good. They replaced the CPU and I just tested Automoblista, 60 FPS at high settings, no problem what so ever, CPU staying under 80 C at all times... More testing will be done, but for now, upgrading this to a 3 star Laptop. Also Asus, if I could give your customer support a separate score, 10 out of 10. In less than 10 minutes I got a hold of someone, told them what was going on, and they sent me a prepaid packing label via Fedex to my email. Stupidly simple, stupidly easy. Quick edit, I have contacted Asus customer service and they are going to repair my computer for free. I will keep you updated as per the performance once I get it back. As it says on the title. I tried a whole bunch of games, and all show the same basic principle of the CPU massively overheating under any sort of load. This makes for unplayable frame rates, and horrible performance. I've tried a couple of things to attempt the cool it, including lifting the PC and putting a small fan under the computer. This had no effect. CPU hovers around 81'c and climbs up to about 100'C before throttling. Meanwhile the GPU stays 48'-56'C at all times. I have a feeling this is a lemon, and will be contacting customer service to see what the warranty can do about this, will update. But for $1000 this is pathetic... As of now, I cannot recommend... Games tested Iracing Train Simulator Transport Fever Roller Coaster Tycoons 1-3 Nascar Racing Season 2003 Need For Speed Shift 2 Unleashed Need For Speed Hot Pursuit American Truck Sim Payday 2 Automoblista

reviews.name: Chris
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on July 3, 2019
reviews.title: Great Laptop
reviews.review_text: Only had the laptop for 3 days however I did test enough things that I feel confidant I can give gamers a good review as I know what reviews mean to me from the gameing community. I ran Heroes of the storm so the computing power is powerful, I also ran Dark Age of Camelot which is an old game but whats important about that is that I ran DAoC, Discord, 18 website tabs, youtube, Netflix, and Pandora at the same time... no issues at all no frame rates while gameing, and yes it was all done in testing because why else would I want Pandora and youtube and Netflix running at the same time. Great laptop, only complaint is that it is a bit on the heavy side, you can tell that you have something on your lap. but the fans work great at dispersing heat and the where the vents are on the back rather the below or on the side are advantageous to the cooling system and I never ran into heating problems. I cannot attest to long term but I will say that in the future I have found my laptop for when I'm ready to get one again. Great computer and being backed by amazons return policy makes it even better.

reviews.name: Taylor Allen
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on June 10, 2019
reviews.title: Great Machine, just not the one I got
reviews.review_text: I wanted to love this device. On paper, the specs are great and while I had it, it performed admirably. They just need to fix the thermals. While gaming, my machine's CPU averaged 90 degrees Celsius which is way too hot in my opinion. The highest I saw was 98 in a few games. I ultimately worked with ASUS to try Bios updates, re-imaging the device (which led me to lose the TUF-themed armoury crate software and I couldn't get those tools back). Ultimately I ended up returning the device and am now looking at the Zephyrus G ga502 which has reported better thermals to prevent throttling and ultimately a machine burn-out. Hopefully your machine fares better because this thing was beautiful.

reviews.name: JT
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on May 25, 2019
reviews.title: Great value for the money.
reviews.review_text: I bought this laptop to game on the road and to edit my videos from anywhere in the house or country. This laptop is a beast. It play everything almost as good as my home setup. Lighting fast, graphics are pretty good thanks to the 1660ti The ryzen 7 5500h although only 4 cores still works anything your doing with ease. Only thing I'm angry about is.... In the pictures it portrays that laptop to have gold keys. They are not. they are black. It's just aesthetics but still was hoping for the gold keys.  They are rgb but cant get it to look like the picture. This is why only 4 stars.

reviews.name: Kevin F
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on September 21, 2019
reviews.title: Looked amazing, Didn't last..Do Not Buy!
reviews.review_text: First off: I only used this laptop for steam gaming and a bit of school with powerpoint and word. While this laptop is very sleek looking and lightweight compared to my 9 year old still running Toshiba, it definitely has minor issues that need to be worked on. One being the battery of less than 1.5 hours, I have never had a laptop with this low amount of battery that even the best battery setting is horrible. On another note, I had had a few issues since I first received the laptop such as: black screening and even white screening while watching youtube videos and switching tabs to another video, constant Blue Screens of Death within the first few weeks(still happening) likely because of outdated drivers that wouldn't properly update or even install..or just bad incompatible parts put together, and SO many non responsive on my apps and games that the framerate drops. I got so fed up with the slow loading for my apps that I ended up reseting the laptop only to have it still as slow and horrible as before. Switching between two open and used tabs should't take 3 seconds for it to open each tab. Nor should it not be able to even fully run (java)minecraft of all things. Highly suggest not to buy until Asus does something about these laptops or makes a better and proper laptop. This was my third chance to Asus and it was blown away...along with my $1,100 that someone's likely saving in their bank account. While It's still under warranty, I'm not even sure if I should even turn it in for 'possible repairs' if I could even get the customer support that's non-existant. Pros: Quiet(but does rev up and down which is kind of annoying) Doesn't overheat Display Alot better than my Toshiba(performance/specs) Expandable and plenty of slots for external devices. Starting out it was pretty fast, then deteriorated downhill.. Cons: Speakers aren't the best RGB lights you cant change. Black screenings seem to come with it and performance decreases overtime Trackpad isn't always responsive to heavy/light touches. Bad drivers and pieces; BSOD's 'Silent Mode' So much more. No disc drive Tested: TechnicLauncher(minecraft modpacks) Minecraft(Java)(Also was good until it became unloadable/unresponsive and takes over 5-7 minutes to load to the main menu) AoW Planetfall(great until slow and lags) Raft(was good for while and got unplayable by lag/crashes.) Discord(would crash multiple times on startup) Stardew Valley(no issues) Elite Dangerous(great until crashes) WoW(became unplayable/unloadable) The Isle(lag+unresponsiveness) 911 Operator(multiple unresponsive stalls, lags every so often and makes a horrible series of sounds as if its bluescreening)

reviews.name: Amazon Customer
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on April 26, 2020
reviews.title: Great budget gaming laptop with some very small, negligable con's
reviews.review_text: This laptop arrived on my doorstep on February 9th, 2020 and had no issues out of the box. I plugged it into my monitor, plugged a keyboard and mouse in, and downloaded the Resident Evil 2 remake. This laptop will run the game on high settings, however the fans will be very loud and the CPU will be working very hard. I just want to mention this as a sort of rough benchmark, though we'll get into more specifics in just a minute. First, let's look at the pro's and con's of this laptop. Now, just to get a subjective opinion out of the way, I do not take my laptop out of the house very often. That being said, there's no reason why I wouldn't. It weighs roughly 5 pounds which doesn't really seem too heavy to me, but obviously you be your own judge. Pro's: * Has played everything I've thrown at it * Apparently can run Linux (I run Linux, you can run whatever you want) * The keyboard is I believe a chiclet keyboard, but honestly it's one of the best feeling chiclet keyboards I've used in recent memory * The screen has a solid 120 hertz refresh rate and some pretty decent viewing angles for the price. I will say that there are some bright spots, which might bug some people, but I don't mind them so much. * Build quality is something I look for in all of my laptops, and this one was obviously no exception. The body is all plastic, but it's a solid feeling plastic that's kind of rigid and doesn't flex much but also doesn't feel brittle. * The hinge is actually also very sturdy. I did not think this would be the case, and worried about the amount of closing/opening it would have to endure. After a few months, I'm happy to report that it feels no different than when I first bought it. Again, only 2 months at this point, but I've had more expensive laptops break in less time. I'll call it a positive. Con's: * Look, the touchpad just sucks. If you plan on using this touchpad for any kind of serious work, just get a mouse. It's finicky, often deciding that I have a ghost finger touching in the opposite place as my finger, or that the three clicks I just did were all right clicks. Frankly, it's kind of a headache, but I mean a mouse is better anyway. * The battery life is pretty mediocre for a normal, business class laptop and downright abysmal when you're gaming. Think 2 hours of Resident Evil before you have to think about how much progress you're going to lose in the next 15-20 minutes. Leave it plugged in for intense gaming, surfing the web and watching youtube will get you about 4-5 hours, depending on your settings. * This laptop only comes with the 256gb nvme flash memory. This is great as a boot drive and pretty much nothing else. It does not come with a hard drive by traditional standards, and the space provided is not enough for any kind of gaming library. You'll likely want to get a 1tb hard drive or SSD, that should hold most of your stuff. Or get a different size, I'm not your mom. * I/O is not great. All of the ports on this laptop are on the left hand side of the laptop, meaning that there are not very many of them, and yet they still feel kind of cramped. In total, there are three usb ports (1 of which is USB 2.0, the other two are USB 3.0) an HDMI port, an Ethernet port, the charging port, and a headphone jack. There is no card reader, no thunderbolt, no USB-c. On the other side of the laptop you'll find a kensington lock, for all of your kensington purposes. I just kind of feel like they could have put in a card reader and maybe another USB or HDMI on the other side, but it doesn't bug me too much. * Finally, and this is more a gripe about the current state of windows as a whole, but this laptop does come with a fair amount of bloatware. I randomly find things like Bejewelled or Fruit Ninja and their lookalikes downloaded on my boot drive. Thank Linus for Linux, yikes. Now something that I do want to address, this CPU (Ryzen 5 R5-3550h with Vega 8 IGPU) is not the toughest CPU out there. It's comparable to some of the low end i5's that Intel has been putting out, but it does only have a base clock speed of 2.1 GHZ and a boosted clock speed of 3.7 GHZ. This means that the CPU does sometimes get very hot for what seems like lower quality games, but the reality is that those games may be more CPU intensive. A good example I found was Terraria. It runs fine, but not when I was doing five other things in the background. Just some food for thought, it hasn't really impacted my feeling about this laptop, but you should know what you're getting before you get it. Finally, I want to mention the Armoury Crate program that is shipped with ROG and TUF laptops from Asus. I personally really like the interface, and it's one of few thing's I'll miss when I switch to Linux. It really does give you all of the real time performance info you need, as well as allowing you to control certain effects for your keyboard or what GPU will be used. You can also buy devices that link to your laptop and use the same RGB effects (For all you REAL gamers out there.) To sum this whole thing up, I was pleasantly surprised. I wasn't really expecting the build quality to be great, I wasn't expecting a really good keyboard, and I wasn't really expecting to be able to throw Linux on here. Lots of good surprises, not many bad ones. The touchpad sucks, but this IS still a budget laptop. I would and have recommended this laptop to friends and family alike, and am excited to see how long I can run modern titles with this lovely machine. I don't want to say "Get this NOW!!!!" or anything, but I did a lot of shopping and found nothing better for the price, so take that how you want to. Thanks for reading! If you've made it this far, have a great rest of your day!

reviews.name: Pixie Power! ®
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2019
reviews.title: Great Gaming PC in this price point
reviews.review_text: Pros: the laptop is built to standards making it capable of remaining intact with some rough handling.  It has a full keyboard including 10-key.  A program for controlling the keyboard lights to a simple degree.  The keyboard is backlit.  They touchpad is large enough for those who prefer it. Cons:  I've had 2 blue screen moments, and 3 times I had to reboot because the network card stopped seeing the internet.  It saw the connection, connected.  But, had DNS issues. The 10 key keys are too narrow for touch typing & 10key by touch.  The touch pad location makes typing impact the touch pad. I've disabled the touch pad and added a mouse and full size keyboard.  The added keyboard lighting controls are far advanced over the ones Asus provides for TUF. By disabling the touchpad, most of my major frustrations are resolved.  I purchased this on a payment plan.  But wish I'd purchased the 17 inch screen model instead. I've also purchased the i5 version of this laptop with half the memory.  Playing the same online game, there's a slight barely noticeable difference between the two. Overall, it performs well.  You can tell the differences in the laptop versions of the CPU and GPU from the desktop versions of the same models. The processor runs hot under normal non game use.  I've programmed the external add on keyboard to track both the CPU & GPU temperatures.  So can monitor during uses & functions. Overall, it's working well.  I will put an external fan to cool it on it soon.  I needed to be able to take it in the go if internet goes down.  As a gaming laptop goes in this price range, it's hard to beat.

reviews.name: Misu
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2019
reviews.title: Really wanted to love it, but too many problems
reviews.review_text: Initially I was very excited to receive the laptop. It's the first gaming laptop I buy in years so I was really happy to have found an AMD Ryzen system as my last gaming desktop was also an AMD system and it was amazing. Ordered this for a trip so I could relax and game while on vacation. I wish I had had the time to test it at home because it proved to be frustrating. My unit gets incredibly hot. I don't even have to be gaming for it to get uncomfortably hot. While on vacation, I had to buy a small laptop table just to use it because it would burn my legs. I tried everything, including setting the fans on turbo at all times. It's loud and that seems to help but as soon as I start gaming, 15 minutes into whatever game I'm playing, frame rates begin dipping and the game will freeze because the laptop is getting so hot. I I installed an app that measures the CPU and GPU temps and overlays those values while I play and my unit's GPU is routinely hitting over 90C. From everything I've read, that's too hot and it shows in performance. The battery is also awful. I have to be plugged in all the time or else I'm out of battery within an hour. It makes using the laptop while being mobile a pain because I have to be near a wall socket to plug in the charger. Basically I can't use the laptop anywhere I want, I always have to be plugged in and near a wall to do it. The WiFi is awful, too. Very slow. I've updated everything, via both the manufacturer website as well as Windows updates. The BIOS also updated and the WiFi is very slow. I can test the speeds using other wireless devices to check if it's my internet and our connection is fine. My connection at my home routinely hits 90 to 100 MPS. But this laptop will show me speeds of 15 to 25 MPS on the same connection. I don't know if the motherboard is the issue or what. And today my screen went black while using it and wouldn't turn back on for a few minutes. Then, on its own, it turned back on. Thats enough for me to make the decision to return it. I'm still within my return window so I'm going to go ahead and issue the return now and look into another model. It's a shame because I've got two Asus vivobooks for productivity and Netflix watching and they are excellent so I had the same expectation of excellence with this laptop. Asus makes really good computers, that's always been by experience. I just think I got a bad unit so I'm gonna go ahead and return it and look for another model.

reviews.name: Michael
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2019
reviews.title: Fantastic value
reviews.review_text: Though I only purchased this laptop recently, its specs at $1099 warrant a close look from anyone looking for a solid, do-it-all laptop for a great price. PROS: The specs. Seriously. Find a better deal for a non-sale laptop of similar size. If you do, go out and buy a lottery ticket. 100% the best non-sale value of any factory laptop you'll find. If this laptop ever does go on sale, don't hesitate or second-guess yourself if you can afford it and you need/want a new laptop. This is the one to get. Fast, especially if you're like me and going from only HDDs to an OS on the SSD with room to spare AND a secondary 1TB HDD. From off to desktop in five seconds. Gaming: This is a great rig for gaming. Even intensive games don't completely tax this laptop (Unless you're playing Cities: Skylines with 1,300 mods installed). It plays Witcher 3 on Ultra and maintains 60FPS ALMOST all the time. Rock-solid 60FPS on High settings. Bloatware: There's not a whole lot compared to your usual suspects, which is extremely refreshing. CONS: Quiet? Not really. It's not very loud even at its loudest, but it's also not very quiet. The fans do a great job of keeping the Ryzen 7 CPU nice and cool, but that also means when it's under any amount of real load the fans are switched on, and you'll know unless you have wrap-around headphones on. Backlighting: This is a personal con to me. The backlighting settings aren't very intuitive and take some time getting to where you want it. But damn if it doesn't look pretty right out of the box going through the rainbow. Drivers: You'll have driver issues. Even after you update every driver, you'll still have driver issues. You'll have them until your third week in. Why? I don't know. Sometimes if you plug in your headphones, it sounds extremely strange until you do a restart. If you're patient, this won't bother you. If you're like me, people will ask why you're calling your laptop a finicky bitch under your breath. Audio: The Realtek audio doesn't seem to be the same as the one on my Dell, which is what this replaced. The audio isn't as crisp, especially without Dell's additional settings and audio suite. If you listen to a lot of music on your laptop, you'll notice the difference immediately. It's not terrible, but in my book it's a con when songs don't sound the same across different laptops. Battery: This laptop was meant to be plugged in while in use. It is readily apparent if you use it on battery life alone, even on power-saver settings. It'll last three, maybe four hours doing light work/browsing. Not great, but far from the worst I've seen. That's about it. If you're hesitant about getting an AMD laptop due to the overheating stories you've heard, you can rest a fair bit easier once you realize that the fans in this thing work very, very well and that it'll only burst into flames when you try to load  your 1,301st mod in Cities: Skylines.

reviews.name: Björn Þorkelsson
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on June 11, 2019
reviews.title: My experience alone (faulty unit).
reviews.review_text: CPU overheating to 103°C while gaming (AMD states Max is 105°C). Did try clean Windows 10 1903 with Asus driver (from Asus Website). Clean install with Windows update drivers and latest drivers from Nvidia and AMD sites (chipset and graphics). Had the latest bios 305@thetime. Turbo, balanced fan settings changed nothing (although a lot louder in Turbo). When gaming CPU would reach +100°C and the game would hit one digit FPS for few seconds. The right fan seemed to be pushing less air, but has two exhausts so that might explain the difference in airflow between the two fans. Returning for another, as I have seen good reviews.

reviews.name: Aaron Ueblacker
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2019
reviews.title: Great Price For The Power
reviews.review_text: This laptop for the most part is what I was looking for. Pros: Free-sync, strong body, keyboard is good, great RAM speed. Cons: Vega support is not there or is hard to setup, Speakers are on the low end, APU will thermal throttle under max load. It's a wonderful laptop for the price and if you want the top of the line for AMD then this is your best choice. For me I do need more storage, I didn't find it hard to just buy my own Hard drives to upgrade because the originals were so cheap.  I was a bit disappointed with the cooling for the APU, I did replace the thermal compound and the original was all dry... But over my 6 year old Laptop it destroys it out of the water and this laptop is 30% more powerful then my last desktop build and 3 times cheaper.

reviews.name: Sean A Oxford
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on August 23, 2019
reviews.title: This is a joke...
reviews.review_text: I'm pretty tech savvy, I read all the negative reviews and assumed it was just individuals that didn't know how to troubleshoot. This laptop is a mess. The drivers are improperly installed and causes tons of visual glitches in chrome and low-intensive games. Hell, even the mouse experiences stuttering/frame rates/freezing in the OS, which most people should know is a very. bad. sign. The official driver support website for this model by ASUS is a nightmare, the driver installers just give a command prompt that either does nothing or times out repeatedly. Getting blue screens now and then. This laptop sounds like a diesel engine half the time. The WiFi chip stops working every time it sleeps. The mouse pad is beyond annoying and goes into this "sleep mode" where it wont immediately move when you touch it. The screen's gamma keeps resetting to something ridiculous. The headphone jack doesn't work 75% of the time. I hate leaving bad reviews but they brought this upon themselves. As far as I can tell, they just took a bunch of expensive components and ductaped them together. I think this is the worst purchase I've ever made.

reviews.name: dwcleck
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on December 3, 2019
reviews.title: Great gaming laptop
reviews.review_text: This laptop is great for gaming. It is a hefty laptop but it’s not meant for travel as much as gaming. It also has a somewhat short battery life.  But it’s running some powerful games. Just plug in. It’s easy to upgrade the HD and add more DDR 4 RAM. And does not void the warranty.  Mine now has an additional 480 GB SSD and 16 GB of RAM total. 16 gigs of ram in two sticks of 8 allows dual channel RAM which helps a lot. I set the default app installation folder in Windows 10 to the addl SSD drive letter and that’s where new installs go.  It boots in less than 10 seconds. Seems sturdy. And the RGB keyboard is fun. It comes with windows 10 home for the OS. Overall I recommend this for the gamer that doesn’t necessarily need to play the very latest games on full.  But all games I’ve thrown at it work well on pretty high settings or even full. Grim Dawn, torchlight 1 and 2 dungeon siege victor vran  and others. And for the price point this got me exactly what I needed. Paying up to $400 more to move to an i7 was just not worth it.

reviews.name: JLL
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on July 10, 2019
reviews.title: Go Beyond First Impression
reviews.review_text: Start up was very user friendly, with Cortana talking you through various steps and features.  Then I tried to connect to the WiFi; after much time and difficulty, it eventually did. However, the system would keep losing the WiFi, while all my other systems were having no issues.  It took a couple days, since this is an at home working machine and not being used for gaming, to track down that there is a known problem with the WiFi driver loaded on these machines.  Once I manually got it to update driver, it has been working beautifully.  The screen is comfortable for working on Excel files, with plots.  This is my 4th ASUS machine, first laptop; the others are netbooks.  The first netbook fell apart along the hinge. the second still works, with petting along, the face of the screen became unstuck.  Did try the crazy glue solution, but it didn't last.  The 3rd netbook is still fairly new, works well and an ideal weight for travelling and keeping track while away.  I am looking forward to seeing if the various structural challenges I had with other ASUS machines have been completely overcome, at this stage.  Given environmental deterioration, it is not right that computers are designed to become obsolete to force us to purchase updated ones.  This machine has a wonderfully robust looking design.  Hope that is reflected in reality.

reviews.name: Amazon Customer
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2019
reviews.title: Immediately had problems
reviews.review_text: As soon as I started it up, the screen went black and the computer was unresponsive. Upon restarting it, it tried to update BIOS unprompted and then conducted a failed repair afterwards. A complete waste of time, especially for someone who needs a laptop for work. Update: After a couple of updates, the computer still has issues and freezes at random times. Instead of the screen going black, however, it simply freezes and must be restarted in order to restore it. Again, do not waste money on this laptop. Update: Asus was very quick about attempting to repair the computer to fix issues, however, I'm fairly certain all they did was perform a factory reset instead of looking into the actual issue. All the problems I had before have persisted and now I can't even log into my windows account on the device. Still extremely dissatisfied with this product. Avoid, if at all possible. (Second and Third picture/video are issues that worsened after the "repair".)

reviews.name: Felipe Alfaro
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on June 5, 2019
reviews.title: Best Gaming Laptop ever
reviews.review_text: The model TUF505DU-EB74 is way better than I expected , I don't think is fair for this model share reviews with the others models that are quite below standard compared to this one, this laptop hit the 5 star for sure, ryzen 7 3750H impressive almost as powerful as my desktop pc cpu i7 6700k, that is very very good for a laptop , and the gtx 1660ti as soon I read about it I knew would be prefect on laptop in price and power run all games ultra graphics. And for Asus I was really really happy that they didn't add any bullshit programs which they usually do , what a surprise when I turned on the laptop for first time and the only 2 app in the screen are recycle bin and Microsoft edge. Also 1 month free of McAfee not bad I guess. Overall super happy with this laptop!!

reviews.name: Dan
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on July 17, 2019
reviews.title: Too many minor issues that could lead to major ones.
reviews.review_text: Specs wise this is a very solid computer. On arrival, this computer was already running into some issues. RGB keyboard black light cycled through rainbow colors and the gpu fan could not be controlled through their shotty app called armorycrate. Through countless software updates eventually it would just lock up my computer because I believe this computer software is coded for intel processors and not AMD. I sent it into amazon repairs and they got keyboard light working. I asked them how did they do it just in the case it happened again in the future and the technician said he had no idea... A week after the laptop was returned to me “fixed”, the same issues persisted. I chose to try fixing the software again by uninstalling and reinstalling but this time my computer went into windows 10 error mode and now will not give me the option to log in.  It was a fun laptop while it worked but I’m avoiding asus until they get their products fixed... Don’t buy.

reviews.name: Tim Curry
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on November 3, 2019
reviews.title: If you like Laptops that crash, this might be the one for you.
reviews.review_text: Laptop is a huge waste of $700. Oh you want to watch youtube, nah I'll crash. Oh you want to game, Nah I'll crash. Oh you want to turn me on, Nah I'll crash mid startup. I have a desktop computer at home built for gaming, so I bought this cause I spend a lot of time away from home and my last laptop was 5 years old and is just so slow it just wasn't worth it, so I bought this laptop to satisfy me hopefully being at a faster speed. The only thing that's fast about her is how fast she crashes. Who knows maybe I just got a lemon and I'm writing this bad review for no reason, either way I'm still mad at myself for purchasing this.

reviews.name: Pop-Tart
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2019
reviews.title: Great so far
reviews.review_text: I was very impressed by the item description and read a couple of reviews and quickly purchased the ASUS TUF (2019) Gaming Laptop, 15.6” 120Hz Full HD IPS-Type, AMD Ryzen 7 3750H, GeForce GTX 1650, 8GB DDR4, 512GB PCIe SSD version.  While waiting for UPS to deliver the laptop, as it needed a signature, I started reading all the reviews. I quickly became very concerned with the reviews detailing the BSOD's and black screens. I then googled video reviews, and found that almost all reviewers by professional techs recommended this laptop as a beginner's gaming machine. I have now used the laptop for approximately 12 hours and have these observations. First the negative. I HATE that all USB slots are on the left side of the laptop. There is nothing on the right side. I spend a lot of time gaming and laying down with the laptop on my belly and I have my left hand resting on the left side as I constantly use the Function 1-4 keys. The USB plug in adapter is rubbing a blister on my hand as there is no way to avoid it unless I don't use a mouse, which is unacceptable. The arrow keys are a little to far towards the middle, so I had to program the number pad keys for moving in game. Also, the F1 key starts too far to the right, so I have had to program my gaming keys somewhat. With that said, the laptop runs smoothly, is very quiet and does not run hot at all. Now I only play Everquest which is not a demanding game for a PC, but there is no heat or noise from the fans. I like the keyboard other than what I described above, and have no idea why some people have complained about the keyboard and touch pad. The lighted keyboard does change colors, but it isn't a distraction for me at all, so I haven't tried to change it to stay at one color as of yet. So I like this laptop. If I experience any issues I will update my review.

reviews.name: Radashack
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2019
reviews.title: As Long As You Don't Use the Camera or Expect A Lot Of Good Gaming Sound, This Machine Could Be It!
reviews.review_text: This machine was delivered last week but I did not have an opportunity to set it up until two days ago. I was very impressed with the styling, clarity and brightness of the display, and the ease in setting it up. When I began to use it I noticed two things that were unacceptable. One is the camera. The color is completely gone and the image is so dark, that unless you're sitting in a bright room or under a movie arc lamp, it is essentially useless. The second thing is the sound quality. For a gaming laptop you would expect the sound to be very generous, very deep, and very loud. Even at max volume, and that's assuming you not in a crowded room, it sounds like you are in a 100 foot deep tin can. I have a 10-year-old tablet that sounds better than this. I was amazed at how bad it was. So I contacted ASUS customer service, and that was a mistake. They had absolutely no answers and that's when I got them to talk and not either hangup or switch me to a phone that continuously rang. For $600 this machine would be worth it, for $1000 is not! Without playing one game as yet, the fans come on in the unit is very hot. I am returning it!

reviews.name: Ethan T.
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on July 8, 2019
reviews.title: Solid overall performance aside from the mediocre wifi module
reviews.review_text: Solid performance for the cost. Subdued, compact design at home on work travel while providing dedicated graphics. Battery life is acceptable, but not extraordinary which is to be expected from a performance-oriented offering. A few minor gripes: * While the 'Armoury Crate' software has an Aura lighting tab, this is NOT where the keyboard backlight is controlled. This is done under the 'Gaming' -> 'Lighting' tab. Not a big deal once you realize it. * Wireless performance was very lag spikey with the included wireless module. Download speed was okay, but every 8-10s there was a huge latency spike which I could never resolve with multiple driver releases or windows reinstalls. I wound up swapping the module for an inexpensive Intel 9260 module and have been trouble free since.

reviews.name: Chris
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on December 4, 2019
reviews.title: *UPDATE* Wow, just wow! GREAT Value!
reviews.review_text: Update: Battery life is horrible. I put the screen brightness at 50% and I can only get around 3 hours just using Word... Changing review to 3 stars because battery life is very important to me. Got this on the black Friday deal for $599. Great value for the money! Laptop comes ready to upgrade RAM DDR4 (SO-DIMM 2666mhz) and another 2.5" hard drive (SATA). I bought 16GB of RAM and 480GB SSD on Amazon for around $90 total. The upgrade process was easy. Had a little difficulty with the power connector from the battery to the motherboard but got it to work. Make sure you initialize the hard drive and download GeForce Experience to get your video card with the latest drivers. This laptop is very smooth to use, boot time is 11 seconds to login screen. The body feels more plastic than I like but its not a big deal for me. Easy to make adjustments to keyboard colors, fan speed and other options. A lot of reviews complained about the fan noise being loud when gaming, you can hear them but they are not that loud to me. I'm coming from a 5 year old MSI gaming laptop where the fans where very loud. I bought this primarily for documents and light gaming. I mostly play Guild Wars 2 and also SWTOR only when i'm away from my desktop. Game play is very smooth while playing on the 120hz screen. For those that want to know about frame rates in Guild Wars: Lions Arch - Max settings 30-35 FPS Open World - Max settings 50-80 FPS At the time of this review the price has jumped to $799, if you can get this around $600, I thinks its a great deal!

reviews.name: Triplet Reviews
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on April 10, 2020
reviews.title: Very good computer for the price
reviews.review_text: Prior to this computer I had an ASUS gaming laptop that was 3 times the price of this one. I was very happy with it, I've had it for 7 years and it's still able to run MMOs, albeit at low settings. I now have a desktop for gaming and didn't want to invest as much in another high-level gaming laptop, but needed a laptop for work and limited amounts of gaming/videos/etc. Now that I've been working from home for a few weeks (thank you, COVID-19), I've had a chance to spend a good amount of time on this computer. I have not yet tried gaming on it so I can't speak about that - I'll have to come back and update later. I have been working, though, and it's been great, especially for the price. I tend to work pretty RAM-heavily - lots of programs open, lots of browser tabs open - I haven't had any problems at all. I will probably add more RAM at some point anyway, but the amount it comes with is perfectly fine. When watching videos, the screen is nice and crisp with good refresh, but again, I haven't played any games. It seems to stay very cool, which is great as my old ASUS ran a little hot. It's practically silent, which is also nice because my old ASUS fans were a little loud. The keyboard is responsive. The keyboard glow is fun - my kids love it - and it helps me type in low light. The color on the keyboard changes colors and "breathes" - it's fine for me, but I wonder if there's a way to lock it on one color... if there is, I haven't found it yet. It can easily be turned off if it's annoying, though. I do have a few complaints - not big enough for me to subtract a star, but I'd like to mention them nonetheless. 1. The trackpad is left of center. I read other reviews that mentioned this before buying and it didn't sound like a big deal, but it actually is pretty annoying. I, like most people, I assume, use the trackpad with my right hand. Whenever I reach for the trackpad/mouse, it's not where I expect it to be and I end up right-clicking when I mean to left click. I also touch it sometimes with my left hand and end up zooming when I want to just move the mouse. Not a deal-breaker and the fix is obviously to use an external mouse, but I like to have the trackpad option for when I'm traveling with the computer. I'm not sure why they put it to the left of center, but if they had to put it one way or the other, I'd rather it be to the right of center. Notes for next time, ASUS. 2. There are not separate home and end keys. The key is home by default and end with the FN key. I use the home and end keys frequently and having to hit FN to use end is a little annoying. I get that a laptop has limited space, but I would rather have had home and end be primary functions on two of the keys above the numpad and other functions be FN+ functions (I hope this makes sense). Or maybe the plus sign next to the numpad could have been smaller to allow for one more key. There had to have been a way around it. 3. I don't know why, but my space bar has a tendency to double space. I'm a good typist and type on lots of keyboards - I've never had this problem before so I don't think it's something I'm doing, I think it's something to do with the space bar itself. Again, not a huge deal, but just a little gripe. So in summary/TL;DR - Great laptop for the price, a few little tweaks by ASUS would make it even better.

reviews.name: Ed
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 27, 2020
reviews.title: Cheapest 120Hz laptop?
reviews.review_text: First of all, the 120Hz display makes a world of difference. After 5 years of 120Hz desktop displays, 60Hz displays look stuttery and slow. Once you get used to it, theres no going back, and now you can get one in a budget gaming laptop??? The screens great, apart from mediocrity colour reproduction, but a laptop isnt just a screen, what drives the screen is just as important. The gtx1650 and ryzen 5 CPU do an adequet job of driving most modern games into the 90-100fps region at medium settings 1080p. Even though the gtx1650 isnt the most powerful gpu, its enough to see the benifits of 60+ fps gaming in most games, even if some settings may need to be turned down.  I would choose 120Hz screen and medium graphics over 60Hz and high graphics anyday; perhaps laptop screens are too small to really notice graphical improvements from medium-high settings. The model I purchased only has 8GB of ram in single channel. I highly recommend upgrading it to dual channel for improved gaming perfromance- ryzen CPUs love their memeory bandwidth. Boots times and snappiness are noticeably better than my old non-NVME SSD laptop. In other words the included NVME SSD is plenty fast and really appreciated at this budget price point. I also added a extra 500GB SSD. Its alot cheaper to add your own extra storage than buying an upgraded everything laptop ($75 vs $300-400) Everything else is as it should be for a budget gaming laptop- usable keyboard, poor battery life (3-4 hours) average laptop speakers and a mediocre trackpad. Overall I am very pleased with the laptop, it does what its supposed to do: play videos games. In fact it does it fairly well with a 120Hz screen, and at a budget price point at that! The battery life is bad, the screen doesn't have popping colours like a 2 thousand dollar macbook and its not superlight, but thats not why I bought it, I have an ipad for word processing , watching videos and emails. If you want a solid gaming laptop at an amazing price I cannot recommend anything else- the 120hz screen really is a rarity at this price point.

reviews.name: thomas
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2020
reviews.title: better then i was expecting
reviews.review_text: i did alot of comparisons of laptops before i ordered the asus fx505dt and it did not disapoint. the laptop is thicker and tougher then i initially realized which is a bonus since im a bit of a cluts when it comes to handling stuff. the screen is incredibly clear and not a single dead pixel. now the graphics i thought it was just a nvidia gtx 1050 but no it also came with the apu amd vega 8 which when setup right can use one for the main screen and the other to render off to a monitor with no slowdown to games. the battery managed to last me through 4 movies without dyeing after i adjusted the settings. proccessor so far has been setup on auto from 2.4ghz to 4ghz based on system load. it is an awsome laptop and the only downfall is the ram it definitly needs more then 8gb i recomend if you buy one to get a 8gb ram chip or higher for it when possible.

reviews.name: Tony
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on November 17, 2019
reviews.title: Good when it works.
reviews.review_text: Half the time I booted this computer the mouse and keyboard functionality stopped working. I checked in the boot menu and all settings for topic were enabled and the drivers were updated. When it worked, it was great for gaming. Not as good as my GTX 1060 6GB laptop but AAA games can be played on ultra settings even on battery thanks to the Ryzen 5 cpu and battery combination. Mouse and keyboard issues seem like a common problem for Asus laptops. I don't have an external mouse or keyboard so I'm not sure if that will solve the issue. Promptly returning my Laptop. Not worth $730 with tax.

reviews.name: DonJuan
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2020
reviews.title: Glad I purchased this ASUS with Ryzen 7 and GTX 1660ti after much debate.
reviews.review_text: I went back and forth for weeks on which laptop I was going to buy... Read hundreds of articles and watched countless reviews on this computer. I also bought the Ryzen 5 but decided to go all out and get the Ryzen 7 with 1660ti and am glad I did. I utilize this machine as a golfing simulator... This machine runs the golfing software at its highest capacity... It also runs Apex Legends, Destiny 2 with no issues. I'm no PC or Gaming expert, all i can say is this runs everything I've thrown at it with no issues. Another reason I bought this was because you can upgrade components such as the 1tb hdd hard drive to SSD in addition to the RAM. The battery life sucks, even after changing the mode to silent... I knew that prior to the purchase but if you plan on keeping your laptop stationary or within your home you'll love this machine... Just keep the charger close. I also changed power mode to keep battery life at its longest since I am keeping this plugged in 24/7 (I suggest you do the same). NOISE: When running my simulator or playing Apex in turbo mode, its loud.... Performance and Silent Mode - I can barely hear the fan. In case you were concerned with noise, as long as you aren't running games 24/7 it isn't loud and is just like any other laptop. Most reviews will say this laptop is plastic, I can't speak for the cheaper model but the Ryzen 7 has a metal feel to it, very solid with little flexion in keyboard.

reviews.name: Fred C
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on November 17, 2019
reviews.title: Must buy!!
reviews.review_text: This computer is so smooth. Just the right size and weight. Very powerful. Playing Destiny 2 with no issues. Graphics are great. Power up time is about 5-6 seconds. I highly recommend this Gaming Laptop.

reviews.name: David S.
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 1, 2020
reviews.title: Get ready to play and work!
reviews.review_text: I love this laptop because it is a mid-range gaming laptop and can play most DX11 - DX 12 games with ease on moderate settings. Its not by far high end but the specs are nice. The laptop is whisper quiet for everyday workloads and can hold as much as a 7 hour battery life just doing that. AMD Ryzen is a cool CPU and you still wouldn't have to worry about it with such excellent cooling built in. I love how this laptop ships with a M.2, Although for the price of the M.2 I wish I wish Asus went with Samsung or Seagate instead of Western Digital. But the Laptop does have expansion for a 2.5in SSD for additional space. Backlight Keyboard in RGB and you can pick whatever color you want. Additonally this laptop does come with dual graphics, It has AMD's Vega 8 and Nivida Discrete just FYI. Overall excellent laptop for anyone and I recommend it fully!

reviews.name: Jon F.
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2020
reviews.title: Great performance and value without breaking the bank
reviews.review_text: This is an amazing entry level gaming laptop. It performs well with emulators. I ran Quake 4 and the frame rates were great. Putting at the highest setting caused the game to dump me out to the Desktop and leaving my screen in a weird state which was resolved with a reboot. It boots up very quickly and shut down just as quick. It has an empty bay for a 2.5" HDD or SDD, and the RAM and NVMe SSD can be changed out. Only downside was the choice of ports. This laptop comes with a USB 2.0 port, and two USB 3.1 Gen 2 ports, but no USB-C ports. I do find the inclusion of a USB 2.0 port odd, considering the fact that the two USB 3.1 Gen 2 ports are backwards compatible with USB 2.0. Also, the lack of USB-C ports are also odd, as most laptops have them. Keep that in mind when purchasing this laptop. Other than those, this is a great value for the money that won't break the bank.

reviews.name: Mauricio Rivas
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2019
reviews.title: Excelente
reviews.review_text: UPDATE: La mejor recomendación que les puedo dar con un procesador Ryzen es utilizar RAM EN DUAL CHANNEL, el rendimiento mejoró en casi un 50% en fps en juegos. Llegó antes y todo perfecto, los altavoces no son los mejores pero considerando que casi siempre utilizo audífonos no es un problema para mi, es rápida, buen price y discreta. La recomiendo.

reviews.name: larry daniel workman
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on December 4, 2019
reviews.title: Best budget gaming laptop 2019
reviews.review_text: Looking for a budget gaming laptop to run all your games on high-max settings for under $1,000? Look no further because this laptop will meet your every gaming need! Out of the box it took about 10 seconds to boot which really surprised me (never owned a pc with an ssd) The lights shine very well on the keyboard and the screen is absolutely flawless! Been using the laptop now for a few hours now and the laptop runs at a very nice temp 46C for the GPU I have not owned a gaming laptop in a very long time and really wanted to get back into gaming, this laptop will allow me to run anything I throw at it. I do not do very many reviews but I felt the need to tell others just how good this laptop is. Asus knows how to make a gaming machine!

reviews.name: Thivus
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2020
reviews.title: Excellent but with a few odd quirks
reviews.review_text: Purchased as an upgrade to my old desktop that had an i3 and a gtx 950 and couldn't do much anymore. Wanted to e able to play Devil May Cry 5, and also have something portable I can take to university and work on projects with. Can handle the games I enjoy playing at high or max settings and 60fps, no problem. Specs should be able to handle most modern games.  No problems with sound or brightness either. I like the glowing keys but I think you can turn them off in the armoryCrate app if you don't like them. A few odd quirks though. First, the MyAsus feature will always tell you that it needs to update, but then you will go to the MyAsus panel and there are no new updates to take. Very annoying and you will need to disable notificartrions for sanity's sake. Second, I don't know what causes this but sometimes after going into sleep mode it won't wake back up again. Keyboard won't work, screen is frozen, all you can do is completely restart the machine. Not a big deal but a little worrying Don't expect much from the battery when you don't have it plugged in. I think mine lasts about an hour, maybe two if I set it to power saving mode. If you plan on doing any serious work or gaming you better find somewhere to charge up

reviews.name: Amazon Customer
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on July 16, 2019
reviews.title: Solid laptop with a little false advertising
reviews.review_text: This is a solid gaming laptop capable of rendering detailed graphics. It's blazing fast and has been very fun to own. However, the pictures do not accurately portray the RGB keyboard. The space bar does not light up as shown, and the RGB function is basically broken. Although there are settings for it in the Armoury Crate software, these do not work. Instead, you have to download a separate tool, the TUF Aura Core. Even then, while the controls in that app do work, the brightness setting has absolutely no effect. This means you can either have a fairly bright rainbow vomit keyboard, or you can change the settings in the TUF Aura Core app at the cost of making your keyboard much dimmer. If the RGB keyboard had not been flawed, I would have given this five stars, as ASUS is not responsible for the many bugs in Windows 10. However, the misleading pictures together with how dim the keyboard is outside of its default mode merit the removal of one star.

reviews.name: Ming
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2019
reviews.title: Junk. Stay away from this.
reviews.review_text: Got this laptop for my nephew for his college graduation and he was excited about it. The laptop label itself a gaming laptop, but it does everything but gaming. The laptop wireless card is so trash that it would disconnect me from online gaming once every 15-20 mins. Ruining my online gaming experience, can never finish a full game on league of legend without being reconnecting back like 2-3 times per game. That goes with all online uses as well, it would disconnect me as I’m browsing the internet or listening to my music. I just return this laptop, on day 21 still no refund back into my account for my holiday shopping. The laptop arrived in their warehouse for over 15 days and yet I don’t have my money. Avoid this laptop at all cost, poor qualify wireless card, bad customer service, and take forever to get your money back.

reviews.name: PJ
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2019
reviews.title: Great budget gaming laptop if you upgrade it
reviews.review_text: Right after unboxing, I tried playing Mass Effect Andromeda on this machine (officially recommended GTX 1060). I did not measure the FPS, but it was "playable" at ultra graphic. I then popped in another stick of ram and a faster SSD, and now Mass Effect runs flawlessly. My only complaints are 1. noisy fans 2. Bluetooth audio stutters 3. Wifi unstable and would randomly drop, and disabled Edit: I replace the lousy wifi/bluetooth module with Intel wifi 9260 module, and all my wifi/bluetooth problems are gone. Shame on ASUS for shipping with such lousy module. Now that my laptop is maxed-out, it works like a dream. I wouldn't want to live with it in the stock condition, though.

reviews.name: Mike
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on November 18, 2019
reviews.title: Handles games great, not so good on battery.
reviews.review_text: After 4 months, This laptop hasn't let me down in performance, the 1660Ti was a great choice. Metro Redux, DOOM, Battlefield 4, Call of Duty Modern Warfare (2019)  all run well over 60 FPS on max settings. Total War Attila runs okay arounds 20-30fps, GTA V runs acceptable at about 45 fps average, both on max settings.  The CPU is a slight bottleneck as well as needing to use the HDD for most games since the SSD is only 240GB, but I plan to put larger SSD's in it in the future to extend its life as a dedicated gaming laptop. The cooling system is powerful to say the least, I only play games on flat surfaces and you can certainly feel the heat blasting out of the side.. The fan gets loud when it's really going, but I don't notice it with a headset on. I haven't had any overheating issues thus far. Video editing using Filmora is reasonably quick, but obviously won't be as fast as processors with more threads. The keyboard feels nice and solid without feeling too spongy like most standard laptop keyboards, but I opted to use a Razor mechanical keyboard when I'm playing games at home because I like the clicky feedback letting me know I pushed the key hard enough. The screen is fantastic for being a 1080p, even though I'm used to playing on larger 4k monitors, the resolution is perfect for its size and games look really good on it. Battery life is pretty sub par and you won't be able to utilize the gaming graphics card without plugging in, but I have gotten about 4 hours using it for work and movies on silent mode. The default keyboard LED setting does kind of an annoying rainbow strobe and Armoury Crate is a bit difficult to navigate to turn it into a solid color. You have to click on device, system and then lighting, it would be better if the keyboard setting was at least in the main menu of armoury crate. With all that said, I definitely recommend this laptop.

reviews.name: Greg Bennett
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2019
reviews.title: Returning to Amazon
reviews.review_text: First of all, I think it's pretty misleading that a lot of the reviews for this product are for other variations with different graphics chipsets. For the record, I purchased the Ryzen 7 3750H with 16 GB RAM, 256 GB SSD, 1 TB HDD, and GTX 1660. It seemed like a really great deal, but I'm returning this laptop to pick up the Lenovo at Costco that has an Intel i7 and 512 SSD with the other specs the same. This is the third Asus laptop I have purchased, and it will probably be the last. They have all had some sort of hardware problem, and I have only kept one out of the three. I know they have made good components in the past, but their laptop business doesn't seem to be up to snuff; they are pretty cheaply built. First, I have been combing the Internet trying to enable processor virtualization, which I need for BOINC and BlueStacks. I tried uninstalling the Asus utilities and updating drivers, but whenever I enable Virtualization in the BIOS, Windows 10 will freeze upon boot. Secondly, the onboard audio sounds like garbage. I tried a couple different versions of the driver; from Asus, Realtek, and Microsoft, and they all sound the same. Very low quality audio through the onboard headphone jack. I use a Logitech headset that comes with a USB audio adapter, I plug that in and there are no problems. Lastly, I've had this thing for less than a month and have had two BSODs related to hardware issues. They might replace it on warranty, but based on this and previous experiences I would feel much better just returning it and trying something else out.

reviews.name: Jarvi
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2020
reviews.title: When it works, its a good laptop for gaming
reviews.review_text: I like this laptop a lot for playing games, including on high graphics settings. The problem is that it seems to be very unreliable. It has blue screened many times since I've had it, about a month or so, including one time that was bad enough that windows stopped loading and I had to use a windows 10 recovery to reinstall. This isn't user error as I am quite experienced with Windows PCs. It is also not always the same thing. For example, most recently I plugged in a USB mouse and it blue screened saying something about the driver. If you are savvy with computers and are patient enough to take care of a laptop as needed, this is a great budget gaming option. I do not recommend this laptop for anyone looking to use it as a primary device or someone who is not experienced enough with computers to know how to fix it when it stops working.

reviews.name: Gordon
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on February 25, 2020
reviews.title: Great gaming laptop
reviews.review_text: First off do not listen to the bad reviews, I bought this laptop with extra 8gig samsung ram and a 2 tb fire cuda hard drive for fast storage on the cheap around 80$. I have this hooked up to a 4k tv using wireless keyboard mouse and a couple xbox controllers. I run it at 1080p not looking to stress the laptop out but video streaming and gaming this thing beats my Xbox one x10. Better yet it's portable and does way more functions then a Xbox One can. I know not a fair comparison how about my house rig it's sitting next to i built Ryzen 5 3600 32 gigs of ram and a Sapphire Nitro RX 590 graphics card 8gigs vram.  This little laptop can fool me when using it that i'm using my big rig, I've yet to experiment with 4k settings but with the laptops amount of vram i don't think it will do well even my desktop rig struggles at 4k gaming.

reviews.name: Stuart B.
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on April 28, 2020
reviews.title: A fine laptop... if it's plugged in.
reviews.review_text: I bought this laptop so I could play a few games, record audio, and do video editing when I'm out and about. In terms of doing all of those things it works pretty well. However, the screen is a little dim and the battery life on this laptop SUCKS! In battery saver mode, I can only get 90 minutes of time on a full charge. That's just standard internet browsing, not gaming or editing. So would I buy this laptop again? Maybe, assuming I can find a way to extend the battery life. I've been lucky in having accesss to power in my shoots but if I didn't have a socket, then this laptop would be a serious problem for me. On the flip side, I would like a USB-C port for faster memory card uploads and a longer battery for non-graphics/processor intensive activities.

reviews.name: NYNNYG
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on November 17, 2019
reviews.title: Asus the Timex of computers
reviews.review_text: Played Outer Worlds on Ultra Quality without a problem. Battery lasts easily for 4-5 hours when working on papers for college. Very solid construction. I have owned many computers from Asus. I have yet to have one fail. I have mistreated them at times and never saw a problem. My daughters laptops are both Asus as well. Oldest dropped hers and has had an excited dog drag it of a table by the power cable...screen was fine still runs perfect.

reviews.name: L. Darthard
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2020
reviews.title: Nice Laptop, but NOT Worth the Original Price.
reviews.review_text: I must be honest. I purchased this Laptop From The Amazon Warehouse for $487. I signed up for a Credit Card and got $125 off that; for a total of $362. I saw this laptop on the sight for around $799 for a while. I did my research, and there were not that many reviews out there. The few I saw for this model were from foreign reviewers (Pakistani or Indian....I was not sure). The Ryzen 5's were not being represented. Now this thing has quirks. It stated that it comes with a 256 PCIe NVMe drive. Mine DID NOT. It had a 256 gig CHEAP M.2 NGFF SSD (2280) drive. Luckily I had a spare NVMe drive (512 GIG), to swap out. It does come with 8 gigs of DDR4 2666 mhz RAM (which the system runs a 2400 Mhz.). I purchased another matching 8 gigs for a total of 16 gigs. I also added a 1 TB Crucial SSD for game storage. I consider myself a seasoned PC builder and troubleshooter. When swapping out the SSD, I didn't have the adapters to do a clone, so I decided to just install from a fresh copy of Windows 10 Home. I downloaded the Drivers and the BIOS'. The installation was "tricky". I was able to figure it out after about 90 minutes of trying to get the system to recognize my USB boot drive. Once installed, I then had to install the drivers, which were NOT in your typical installation format (a bunch of .bat files, and some bum witchery to get them installed). And don't get me started on trying to update the BIOS. Once everything was set up, I was greeted with just a "meh" amount of performance. I have a Dell E5470 with a 6th Gen i5-6440H (with just 4 straight cores, no Hyper Threading), that seems peepier than this thing. That laptop only has the intel HD 530 graphics, and it plays games (albeit only at 720p and a mix of low to medium settings), but that laptop cost me $120 on eBay. The only redeeming factor for this laptop is the nVidia GTX 1650 graphics. That one thing made this laptop bearable. Games look grat at 1080p, and they look look GREAT at 720p. I am still playing "older games" like Fallout 4 (albeit with a TON OF MODS), and the game looks and plays almost as well as my Desktop PC. I started playing Shadow Of The Tomb Raider, (on a mix of medium to low) and at 1080p the game performs great. So in conclusion: Do I Recommend this laptop? Well if you already have a decent Desktop Gaming Rig, and need a portable solution on the cheap - then yes, this is a viable addition. But if this will be your MAIN gaming rig, I'd give it an hard pass, unless you can get it for the price that I did.

reviews.name: smitty
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 29, 2020
reviews.title: Good out of the box great with a couple easy upgrades.
reviews.review_text: With a couple upgrades this thing rocks. If you are coming from a console you will be very impressed. If you are used to a high end desktop this is not that. Upgrades: 1, added another stick of ram. 2, added a SSD for more storage. 3, switched to a better WiFi/Bluetooth module. Not necessary for most but if you plan to use Nvidia game share on a shield to play on your TV, it will need to be done. Have achieved 120+ fps on all my games at 1080 high to very high settings (Rocket league, fortnite, GTA V). I did allot of research before buying and I think you cannot find a better value gaming laptop.

reviews.name: Brian DeBerry
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2020
reviews.title: Bought for GF and I'm honestly jealous
reviews.review_text: So my gf's laptop was beginning to fail on her. She'd had her old one for roughly five years and some of the games she wanted to play simply don't work on intergrated intel graphics. Being a gamer and computer hardware enthusiast, I wanted to make sure I got her something that would not only last, but play everything she wanted to play and more. While I'm not not a fan of the 15.6" screen, it looks wonderful. Very fast refresh rate certainly helps. Build quality is just as it says; TUF. The chassis feels very sturdy and though I wouldn't drop it on purpose, I feel like it wouldn't fall apart from an accidental drop or two. Now for some complaints. ALL of the i/o is on the left hand side. The only thing on the right hand side is a kinsington lock. I would have really liked to see at least one usb port on the other side. My other complaint would be no usb-c support. That empty right hand side has plenty of space for one. For a purely cosmetic complaint, I would have really liked to see multi-area lighting support on the keyboard. Overall, if you're looking at purchasing this laptop, I'd say the price to performance just can't be beat right now besides my above complaints.

reviews.name: Kevin
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2019
reviews.title: Burnt out within a month of using it??? Other than that it's a decent laptop
reviews.review_text: Purchasing this product was one of my most regretful decisions of my life. For almost a 1k laptop, it lasted for only for 1 month. Keep in mind that my total gaming hours for each day was less than 3 hours.  That's not even the worst part... Within a week of using it for less than 3 hours of gaming a day this product kept on crashing every time I closed out on Overwatch,CS:GO, and League of Legends. These games can be ran on a 6 year computer with a 610 graphics card. I'm not sure if this whole product is a defect or just mine. Either way I wouldn't risk 1k ever again on Asus gaming  Laptops. Other than the fact that mine died within a month, which I'm upset about because it's 1k and it didn't even last 2 years? A desktop would've been a better choice! The laptop quality was decent,the graphics were decent, and the brightness was decent. The only cons excluding the crashes and burning out within a month, is the battery life. It has at max 3 hours of gaming unplugged.(but it's a gaming laptop so idk why you would want to unplug it)

reviews.name: Garrett
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2019
reviews.title: Blue screens constantly
reviews.review_text: Small and powerful, It's handled everything I've thrown at it pretty well except Netflix or streaming video / swapping windows. I've spent days making sure every driver is up to date, installing / resetting drivers yet this device blue screens about once every other hour. Gaming would be great if you didn't have to reset your PC fully every hours, however the SSD makes resetting the computer rather fast. The BSCOD error code is either Fatal Hardware Error, or Threat Stuck Errors, which have been constant since purchase no matter the updates. I often update this laptop just to see if they have resolved the issue, however no evidence points there. Great laptop, just wish I could use it. Brand new the battery lasts about 3-4x minute episodes of shows before shutting down. It's got shiny RGB's on the keyboard as well .

reviews.name: Borislav
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on July 18, 2019
reviews.title: definitely not for gaming
reviews.review_text: Runs modern games on ultra setting, they get good fps at start but suddenly the fps drops at 10-15 (ex. Witcher 3 , Sid Meyer's CIV 6 , AC Origins, etc. ) and that just kill your gaming session, CPU runs at max all the time 90-98% usage, for a home use is ok , but not for gaming at all.I'm considering a return.

reviews.name: P4EE5GHZ
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2019
reviews.title: It plays games well at 120Hz FHD.  But the fan...
reviews.review_text: Very nice laptop.  I retired my dying 12 year old toshiba for this.  It does everything wonderfully except its' fan control.  I understand and don't want it overheating but when chrome is running there's a high pitched ring.  The kind of ringing that suggests the fans are on low with a pitch high enough to pierce your ears rather badly after 20-30min in a quiet place.  Usually there's noise around so this doesn't matter too much but even putting it on myASUS silent mode(shuts off 1650 and throttles ryzen); it still sounds deafening in quiet places.

reviews.name: Justin
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on December 3, 2019
reviews.title: Do not buy if you like Fn keys
reviews.review_text: The worst laptop I ever had the misfortune of sharing my life experience with. Imagine, imagine making a laptop that doesn't allow you to use the Fn top row keys. You know, the keys that let you control the sound, brightness, and all that stuff? Instead of easily lowering and decreasing the volume while listening to music, I have to manually click the volume slider. That's so tedious and I refuse to go back to doing that. I don't care if this laptop is worth a million dollars and is a super computer. What's the point if it's a tedious and obnoxious paperweight? I hope I'll find a solution soon otherwise I will return this. Come on, ASUS... Seriously? Like, really?

reviews.name: Karl
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2020
reviews.title: Not a true 120hz monitor.
reviews.review_text: Pros: price for the performance you get is quite good. Not great but definitely above average. Cons: First and biggest gripe about this laptop is the monitor it has. It's not really a true 120hz monitor. The response time of the pixels is so slow you can see smearing and ghosting in it. Not really great for fps games like csgo. Changing the video profile to fps mode helps a little bit but still not good enough for playing fps games. If I had a choice I would have returned the laptop because of this but I needed a computer on my way of moving to Japan so I had no choice but to keep it since I got it a day before I leave. The previous desktop I have had rx280 with Intel i5 4690k and at the same settings I was using I was getting around 270 to 300fps in that setup while this is getting 150-170fps. I added another 8gb ram and it made everything run smoother. Really felt the difference about that. I contacted Asus about the monitor maybe I have a lemon but they gave me just drivers that is outdated and of course it didn't help. Asked them if they got a center In Japan and they didn't answer me back. Maybe I could get it replaced thru here in Japan or have the monitor on it replaced but no luck. Anyway if you're main reason is to get this because of the 120hz screen. Look the other way. If you just want a cheap gaming laptop then this is a good one but I'd won't recommend. I'd rather have a 75hz monitor that has no ghosting than this. I uploaded a video of how the ghosting looks in slowmo.

reviews.name: Camellia
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 25, 2020
reviews.title: great machine for gaming, portability is great, and display can be overclocked to 144hz.
reviews.review_text: The battery life when gaming is eh, but when not gaming, the battery life is great! You have to plug the laptop in to get better gaming performance, but when plugged in, it's really good! Over 60fps on GTA V High Settings. Over 100fps on medium-high settings on rainbow six siege. The display can be overclocked to 144hz and it looks amazing at that refresh rate. Also, the sleep mode is really good as well. I would suggest enabling the hibernation mode instead, as after I left it on hibernate for 3 days straight, it didn't lose a SINGLE percentage of battery. Hibernate does the same thing as sleep, but in a lower power state. Overall the gaming experience is great, the battery could be better but is still alright, and the sleep mode (especially if on hibernate) is amazing.

reviews.name: Amazon Customer
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on February 17, 2020
reviews.title: Great overall but a few minor issues.
reviews.review_text: Model purchased was the Asus TUF FX505DT (256 gig, 8 gigs of memory, and Ryzen R5 3550 version) This laptop is great for the price. It's a good middle-of-the-pact laptop. If it's school, gaming, or just general usage, this has got you covered. I've had this laptop for nearly a month now, and it's been pretty solid. You can also upgrade things like the amount of ram and storage space fairly easily, which is a big plus. Gaming: For gaming, I play Yakuza 0, Rocket League, Overwatch, and Civilization 5 (nothing graphically intensive) and usually get around 90-170 fps on medium to high settings. minimal studderring, but the one drawback is to get the most out of the machine, you need to have it plugged in to run at its turbo setting (which also is very loud so I'd suggest investing in some really good headphones unless you don't care about noise.) you can still play it without plugging it in, but obviously to not as stellar results as I couldn't get past 45 fps for Yakuza on medium settings when it wasn't plugged in. I really wish they gave you an option to use the turbo mode without plugging in the battery so that you can get a better test as to how long the battery could last. Another issue is that since you only get 256 gigs of memory (220 with bloatware installed) you have to pick and choose which game you want to download since space can fill up very quickly. Recommend an upgrade to those who get this and plan to do a lot of gaming. Side note, having a 120Hz screen is a big plus, especially for multiplayer games. School: I have it mostly for math and some minor work in Microsoft Office programs. It's been pretty good in that regard, but I did have a weird situation about two weeks ago when I was trying to work and it just crashed for no reason. I wasn't doing anything intensive, but I just went to a black screen and I had to force a restart. General Usage: It does exactly what it needs to for just browsing the web. Though the only eight gigs of ram could become a big issue if you're someone who likes to have eight to ten tabs or more open at once, so I'd recommend an upgrade to sixteen gigs (which is the highest you can get) for this laptop. The rgb settings for the keyboard are optimal and very easy to use. Overall: I'm satisfied with this laptop, despite the minor flaws. It does everything I need it to do and I didn't have to spend 1.5k to get it. As I mentioned, I'd get this laptop if you want to do a decent amount of gaming and not spend top dollar.

reviews.name: matt stewart
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on March 22, 2020
reviews.title: If i had a choice i wouldn't buy it period!
reviews.review_text: Been a few weeks now and the laptop has failed to boot, have tested voltage from wall to laptops power supply, which is good, the tested voltage from power supply to laptop connector, have 18v. now like many am looking at forums online, which people are saying to pull laptop apart and remove battery connector from terminals. should you really have to do this on a new laptop? Save yourself the headache and go for another laptop, battery life will get you three hours tops when running. specs on a budget are so so. Just needed something to write on but like everything nowadays quantity over quality. I probably won't be touching another Asus product after this issue. Sadly i had used their motherboard in my work station. You might have different results but why risk it? - continued. Asus would like to rma laptop that isn’t a month a month old. So basically be out of a laptop quite possible longer then I’ve owned it. After 40 mins of running steps that I knew wouldn’t correct issues.  Trying to return laptop back to amazon. Currently online with amazon to try and figure out how to send unit back that has a battery inside. Head ache! But the whole process is being recorded. So video will be posted up on YouTube once this gets resolved. Maybe saving you time and hassle.

reviews.name: Michael R. Smith
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on February 25, 2020
reviews.title: Looks like a fantastic budget gaming laptop, but it has major problems
reviews.review_text: I was excited to finally have a decent laptop with fantastic features and life like screen, but beneath the features this Asus FX-505DT laptop has major issues....despite long talks with Asus techs, and hours at home, this laptop fails to measure up.  All i wanted to do is use a USB device to run/install some programs and install a dual boot operating system,  despite hours to get the BIOS to respond, this laptop refuses to recognize ANY USB device, any USB device, thumb drive, external dvd player, any USB device.  Even with a purge of the BIOS, and complete reset of Windows 10, this machine refuses to recognize any USB device... A necessary feature in the bios , CSM fails to appear...unable to disable UEFI...and there's .more, which i wont bore you with.  I spoke to Asus techs who told me the USB devices should be recognized if windows 10 was installed and active.  This made no difference...enough.  To say the least, i am disappointed.  I have great respect for Asus brand products for desktop computers, but for this laptop, my first Asus laptop, two thumbs down.

reviews.name: Georgia
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on March 25, 2020
reviews.title: This Laptop Is Awesome!
reviews.review_text: I bought this for my wife to replace her 6-year old Asus Zenbook laptop which was starting to do strange things. I figured it would be just as much work to re-install Windows from scratch and her programs and she would still have an old computer. She is not a gamer, so she won't push it to it's limits, so this review is for those that would just use it as a laptop. This laptop is AWESOME! I was concerned about a few comments indicating they run hot and are loud. It runs cool to the touch and is amazingly fast and quiet. She often uses it while resting on on her thighs and she feels no heat at all. If the fan is running we certainly can't hear it. The screen is wonderful too.........and she raves about the keyboard! The build quality is outstanding and because of the solid state drive it boots extremely fast. I haven't timed it but would estimate boot-time to be in the 10-15 second range. In closing, I like it so much I have thought about buying their ASUS TUF 17.3" FHD Gaming Laptop to replace my Acer Predator Computer.

reviews.name: EngineerKaos
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2019
reviews.title: ASUS I'm a firm supporter but you let me down
reviews.review_text: I'm solid ASUS, my last one still works had for 8 years. Actually gave it to my daughter. I have all Samsung ram, hard drives upgrades. I haven't had more blue screens of death. I have about $1,600 wrapped up in this damn thing. Problem is a Zeus don't kick out any driver upgrade software. And neither does Microsoft.
